item.title: Why there would be no Dgraph 2.0: Goodbye Semantic Versioning
item.description: There would be no Dgraph 2.0. After 4+ years of releasing Dgraph, we have decided to switch away from Semantic Versioning. The next release of Dgraph would be 20.03.0. In this post, we talk about why. Versioning is a complex and opinionated topic. Over the years, weâ€™ve gotten great feedback from our users about our releases. We realize that while making frequent releases helps our users get access to new features and bug fixes, these can also introduce unpredictable breaking changes.

item.title: Whatâ€™s Next? Learn Dgraph with the Getting-Started Blog Series
item.description: We are excited to announce that the “Get Started with Dgraph” of our documentation site now includes the episodes from our getting started blog series. This blog series consists of various tutorials that are helpful for both beginners and intermediates to get started with Dgraph and to understand the product functionalities better. At the time of writing, weâ€™ve published six tutorial episodes, and you can find all of them on the docs.

item.title: Datetime Indexes in Dgraph
item.description: I recently started working at Dgraph Labs in Bengaluru as a Software Engineer. One of the first issues that I worked on was related to the Dgraph’s datetime datatype. This article covers how I discovered and resolved the issue. The article assumes a basic understanding of Dgraph, but you can learn everything you need in docs.dgraph.io. Bug Discovery While working on Flock, I observed that timestamp comparisons were not working correctly in Dgraph when the data or query had timezone information in it.

item.title: Celebrating 10,000 GitHub Stars
item.description: Dgraph is celebrating the milestone of reaching 10,000 GitHub stars ðŸŽ‰. This wouldn’t have happened without all of you, so we want to thank the awesome community for being with us all the way along. This milestone comes at an exciting time for Dgraph. Let’s do quick time-travel through our journey, gaze at our milestones, and wrap it up with a glance through the exciting things in the pipeline.

item.title: Migrating data from SQL to Dgraph
item.description: Dgraph is rapidly gaining reputation as an easy to use database to build apps upon. Many new users of Dgraph have existing relational databases that they want to migrate from. In particular, we get asked a lot about how to migrate data from MySQL to Dgraph. In this article, we present a tool that makes this migration really easy: all a user needs to do is write a small 3 lines configuration file and type in 2 commands.

item.title: How Access Control Works in Dgraph
item.description: With GDPR passing in the EU on April 14th, 2016, users on the Internet are demanding protection of their privacy and data from Internet companies. The regulation has profound implications. Many companies take the law and users’ demand seriously: they start encrypting data for traffic within their data centers, and employing strict control on who can access users’ data. The Dgraph team takes full notice of that. Access control on the data stored in Dgraph is very important to our enterprise customers.
